awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of the First 800 MHz NMR Spectrometer with a Cryogenically Cooled Probe in the State of Oklahoma for Interdisciplinary Research and Training
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program, an award has been made to Oklahoma State University for the acquisition of a 800 MHz NMR instrument with a cryoprobe.  This instrument will be housed in the Oklahoma Statewide Shared NMR Facility to ensure that it is accessible to researchers in Oklahoma and the surrounding region. The new spectrometer will support the training of the next generation of researchers in modern state-of-the-art NMR techniques. Oklahoma State University is aggressively pursing hands-on undergraduate research training through courses, and independent research. In addition, programs in the Chemistry Department such as "Research Experience for Undergraduate Students (REU)" supported by National Science Foundation allows recruitment of undergraduate students across the country. Minority undergraduate students are recruited for research through various undergraduate programs such as the Oklahoma Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (OK-LSAMP). 

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful scientific techniques that is available to scientist for the elucidation of the structure of important molecules. Projects supported by this new instrument span the range from Chemical Biology to protein structure and function, protein dynamics, RNA/DNA structure, complex carbohydrate structure, design of novel polymer, and small complex molecules characterization during the process of drug design. The new NMR is an essential resource for researchers in Chemical Biology, Structural Biology, Biochemistry, Molecular Biology, Microbiology, and Polymer Science across Oklahoma and the surrounding region. The results of these research and teaching efforts will be disseminated through active participation of students and faculty at scientific conferences, symposia and workshops, peer-reviewed publications and the deposition of atomic coordinates of biomolecules to the Protein Data Bank (PDB).

por.por_cntn:
With the support from NSF grant DBI#1726397 (2017-2023), we have purchased and installed the Bruker Neo 800 MHz Spectrometer fitted with a cryogenically cooled probe in the Oklahoma State-wide Shared (OSS) NMR Facility located in the Oklahoma State University campus in 2020.

Intellectual Merit: This is the only high-resolution NMR spectrometer and probe available in the state of Oklahoma and surrounding areas. The PI created a video explaining the OSS NMR facility location, Neo 800 MHz instrument and what can be done with the instrument, how to contact the PI for a private tour, how to contact facility managers for setting up an account, and for training etc. The video has been posted in the Department website and the PI circulated it by sending to researchers in the region.  Despite the COVID-related restrictions in 2020-2021, 4 different virtual training sessions were provided to users including students in the region from October through November of 2020 on the use of the instrument and setting up of various experiments. In addition to the virtual training, on-site training was arranged and provided in August-September of 2021 with higher level use of the instrument including pulse programming. The Bruker Neo 800 MHz spectrometer has been in use and has supported the scientific research in various areas including biological systems related to human diseases and disorders, agricultural systems related to pests and pesticides, carbohydrate chemistry, DNA and RNA, polymer chemistry, and elucidating the structure of complex organic molecules. Users from Oklahoma State University, University of Oklahoma, and surrounding regions including Wichita State University (Kansas) and Texas have been using this state-of-the-art instrument. The major users of this instrument including the students, postdoc-doctoral fellows, and principal investigators have disseminated their research work carried out using the Bruker 800 MHz spectrometer in per-reviewed publications and have presented their research in various National and International conferences. The instrument has supported the doctoral dissertation research work for graduate students. The PI has 6 graduate students whose doctoral dissertation research work was supported by this instrument.

Broader Impact: The funding provided unique opportunities and supported the education and training of diverse body of students and scientists including undergraduate, graduate students, post-doctoral fellows, and researchers /educators in Oklahoma, Kansas, and Texas. Such education and training are indispensable for the development of an effective and highly skilled STEM workforce. The PI has integrated the Bruker 800 MHz instrument in the upper-level undergraduate course (CHEM 4650) and a graduate course (CHEM 6650).  A part of the course requirement of these courses, enrolled students learn both theoretical and hands-on training on the 800 MHz spectrometer. The students learn how to set up multi-dimensional NMR experiment, collect NMR data, process the NMR data both at the instruments terminal and off-line, and analyze the data. Finally, each student writes a report on their work with the 800 MHz instrument that is graded. The PI has trained many students at both undergraduate and graduate levels through these courses. Many of the current and former student users come from backgrounds underrepresented in STEM disciplines. The PI also engaged through collaboration with several local PUI (East Central University, OK and Northeastern State University, Tahlequah, OK) and HBCU (Langston University) in Oklahoma as well as with local high school science teacher and students (Newcastle High School, OK) providing them with hands on experience and tour of the Oklahoma state-wide shared NMR facility that houses state-of-the-art ultra-high magnetic fields NMR spectrometers.
